I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The regional knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support micro, small, 
and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) to recover from the economic effects of the coronavirus 
disease (COVID-19) pandemic and become less vulnerable to a prolonged economic downturn 
in the Pacific developing member countries (DMCs) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB).1 The 
TA will help build and enhance the capabilities of MSMEs affected by COVID-19 to recover and 
grow in the post-pandemic period by (i) strengthening the enabling environment for MSMEs and 
(ii) improving access by MSMEs to business development services and finance.  
 
2.  The  TA  forms  part  of  ADB's  comprehensive  response  to  the  COVID-19  pandemic, 
announced on 13 April 2020, which includes a $20 billion package of loans, grants, and TA. It will 
support the recovery of MSMEs and contribute to ADB’s broader efforts to address the pandemic's 
socioeconomic impacts in its Pacific DMCs. The TA supports ADB's Strategy 2030, including its 
operational priorities 1 (to address the region's remaining poverty and reduce inequalities), 2 (to 
accelerate gender equality), and 6 (to strengthen governance and institutional capacity).2 The TA 
will also contribute to achieving Sustainable Development Goals 8.3, 8.10, and 9.3.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Pacific economies impacted by the coronavirus disease. ADB estimates that losses 
from COVID-19 will total 6.4%–9.7% of global gross domestic product.4 The losses could be 
higher in Pacific DMCs due to their remoteness, small size, wide geographic dispersal, narrow 
economic base, and exposure to disasters triggered by natural hazards.5 The ability of most 
Pacific DMCs to cope with multiple shocks is limited by weak capacity and a lack of resources. 
The health of their economically vulnerable and poor populations is at risk, as health infrastructure 
is inadequate to respond to the pandemic. Recognizing this, Pacific DMCs moved decisively to 
restrict international and domestic travel. These restrictions, combined with the introduction of 
physical distancing measures, helped Pacific DMCs contain the pandemic but negatively affected 
tourism and trade.6 Given the decline in tourism and trade, ADB projects an average economic 
contraction of 6.1% across all Pacific DMCs in 2020. The forecast contraction for 2020 worsens 
to 12.7% when Papua New Guinea, a DMC dependent on resource-based exports, is excluded.7 
Although most Pacific economies are expected to start recovering in 2021, their economic 
performance  is  not  likely  to  recover  to  pre-COVID-19  levels  in  the  short-term  because  of 
uncertainties related to the pandemic and its anticipated prolonged impact on businesses and 
employment levels.8  
 
4.  Micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises particularly impacted. MSMEs lack the 
financial capability to withstand the effects of a prolonged economic downturn. They are critical

to employment and livelihoods but lack the capacity to diversify or consolidate operations. In Asia 
and the Pacific, MSMEs generate 42% of economic activity, and their closures will have a long-
term impact on economic outputs and employment.9 About 89% of businesses in Pacific DMCs, 
most of which are MSMEs, reported adverse effects from the pandemic, and 91% faced reduced 
revenues.10 About 66% of the businesses have reduced their operational costs to counter a drop 
in income.11 The economic disruption caused by the pandemic has also affected access by 
MSMEs to supply chains and markets. By August 2020, 31% of businesses had closed (30% 
temporarily and 1% permanently), and 36% reported a partial reduction in operations (footnote 
10). 
 
5.  Institutional mechanisms to support business recovery are lacking. With support 
from development partners, most Pacific DMCs have provided immediate financial support to 
MSMEs to respond to the pandemic.12 In August 2020, 45% of businesses reported having 
accessed such support, 23% reported needing help but not accessing it, and 20% reported that 
they were unaware of any available support (footnote 10). Designated agencies—such as MSME 
Fiji, Samoa Business Hub, Business and Cooperative Division of Solomon Islands, Business 
Support Division of Tonga, and Chambers of Commerce in the Cook Islands and Vanuatu—have 
supported  their  respective  governments  in  implementing  these  support  measures.  These 
agencies have acknowledged that they lack the capacity and tools to prepare for, and support, 
the post-pandemic recovery of MSMEs. They require support to (i) consider options for recovery 
under  different  scenarios;  (ii)  develop  recovery  frameworks  based  on  key  growth  sectors; 
(iii) strengthen their business support functions, including staff capacity to deliver business 
training; (iv) facilitate training and provide support to MSMEs operating in remote locations; and 
(v) improve coordination and awareness of available MSME support. 
 
6.  Weak enabling environment for micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises. Most 
Pacific DMCs lack an enabling legal and regulatory environment to support the operations of 
MSMEs. Inefficiencies in the regulatory and administrative procedures, including complicated tax 
administration, have resulted in high costs to start, operate, and close businesses. COVID-19 is 
changing business dynamics, and agencies such as MSME Fiji have identified the need to review 
and adjust legislation to suit MSMEs' needs in the post-pandemic period. Many Pacific DMCs 
have  supported  MSMEs,  including  those  in  the  informal  sector,  through  programs  under 
respective ministerial plans  and specific sector  policies.  However, these  programs  are  not 
integrated at the national level to support the formalization and development of MSMEs, and most 
MSMEs continues to operate as informal enterprises. The informality of MSMEs has limited their 
access to broader entrepreneurial support, development programs, and financing. Inadequate 
data on MSMEs has also been identified as a significant challenge in Pacific DMCs, including Fiji 
and the Solomon Islands, making targeted policy interventions difficult. Support to MSMEs need 
to extend beyond recovery and facilitate the formalization of their operations. This will require 
structured government response that include reforms needed to create an enabling business 
environment. By doing this, national governments can spur the recovery, develop the private 
sector, and facilitate private sector-led economic recovery.

7.  Limited  business  capabilities  to  adapt.  MSMEs  in  the  Pacific  have  limited 
preparedness for a protracted economic downturn but remain optimistic about outlasting the 
pandemic. Despite such optimism, the pandemic's impact on businesses is likely to be long-
lasting—37% do not expect revenue to rise to pre-COVID-19 levels in 2021 (footnote 10). MSMEs 
have identified the need for technical, advisory, and financial support to help them (i) manage the 
economic downturn while exploring diversification opportunities (34%); (ii) review, update and 
stabilize their financial position (39%); and (iii) access new markets (33%). By August 2020, 38% 
of the businesses surveyed had diversified, and 22% introduced digital solutions to manage 
disruptions and preserve business continuity (footnote 10). Most Pacific MSMEs rely on traditional 
business models that use manual processes and conduct transactions in person. Adoption of 
technology and contactless solutions have been limited by MSMEs’ (i) competing operational and 
technical  priorities,  (ii)  lack  of  appropriate  information  and  communication  technology 
infrastructure, and (iii) weak technological capabilities.  
 
8.  Poor access to finance accentuated by the coronavirus disease. Governments and 
central  banks  across  Pacific  DMCs  have  introduced  concessional  financing  facilities  to 
supplement  MSMEs'  financing  needs  during  the  pandemic.13 These  facilities  are  available 
through  financial  institutions,  and  thus  MSMEs—especially  those  operating  as  informal 
enterprises—find them inaccessible. Most financial institutions, including commercial banks, 
continue to be reluctant to finance MSMEs because of limited capacity to underwrite and manage 
MSME loans, limited range of financial products available for MSMEs, and lack of acceptable 
collateral,  particularly  land  which  is  mostly  under  communal  ownership  with  no  clear  and 
transferrable titles. MSMEs’ weak financial and business planning skills impede their ability to 
prepare  bankable  proposals. 14  COVID-19  has  stressed  the  income  levels  of  MSMEs, 
accentuating their inability to access finance. Access to finance will be critical for recovery; 88% 
of all businesses surveyed, including MSMEs, identified weak cash flow as a significant challenge, 
with 45% reporting they need finance following the pandemic (footnote 10). Financial institutions 
that are committed to serving MSMEs need to consider alternative approaches to address 
MSMEs’ financing gap in the post-pandemic period; MSMEs need to strengthen their capabilities 
to access credit on an ongoing basis; and policies should be implemented to enable sustainable 
business recovery, including developing properly functioning financial markets.  
 
9.  The  pandemic  disproportionately  affected  women-owned  businesses.  MSMEs 
owned  by  women  operate  under  the  same  regulatory,  institutional,  and  pandemic-related 
conditions as those owned by men. Still, they must overcome additional gender-specific barriers 
to cope with disruptions caused by COVID-19. Close to 91% of businesses owned by women 
have experienced declines in revenue; most operate in the informal sector, meaning their access

business support services critical for recovery is limited by existing gender norms. Restrictions on 
movement because of COVID-19 has led to additional care burdens and reduced the time spent 
by women entrepreneurs on managing their businesses, with 41% of MSMEs owned by women

10.  Lessons learned. Lessons from TA and projects that supported the private sector and 
MSMEs in the Pacific identified the need for interventions to (i) adopt a holistic approach to 
supporting  the  development  of  MSMEs  that  includes  improving  the  business  environment, 
(ii) increase advisory services to serve client needs better, (iii) integrate support for women 
entrepreneurs, (iv) strengthen the capacity of financial institutions inclined to support MSMEs, 
(v) prioritize the use of national consultants, and (vi) strengthen coordination for improved 
collaboration.16 Lessons, including recommendations from a thematic evaluation of ADB support 
for small and medium-sized enterprises during 2005–2017, are incorporated in the TA (footnote 
9). 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: recovery of COVID-19–affected MSMEs 
sustained and their vulnerability to prolonged economic downturn reduced. The TA will have the 
following outcome: capability of MSMEs to recover from the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic 
and grow in the post-pandemic period improved.17  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
12.  Output 1: Enabling environment for recovery and development of micro, small, and 
medium-sized enterprises strengthened. The TA will provide technical expertise to support 
MSME agencies in Pacific DMCs, including but not limited to the Cook Islands, Fiji, Samoa, 
Solomon Islands, and Vanuatu: (i) undertake scenario analysis and plan for recovery of MSMEs, 
including women-owned MSMEs; (ii) develop and strengthen strategies for the recovery of 
MSMEs that includes identifying priority sectors and establishing criteria to select MSMEs for 
support; (iii) improve institutional coordination of MSME support; and (iv) implement and monitor 
government-supported COVID-19 programs for MSMEs, where necessary.18 The TA will also: 
(i) develop and strengthen appropriate legislation and policies, particularly for MSMEs to support 
their formalization and growth in the post-pandemic period;19 (ii) support diagnostic studies at the 
national or regional level that includes assessing the readiness of MSMEs to adopt digital

(iii) support a feasibility study for a national one-stop MSME information-sharing platform; and 
(iv) building on the feasibility study as appropriate, identify a pilot project for the development of 
a national digital one-stop MSME information-sharing platform. The diagnostic studies will include 
gender analysis and sex-disaggregated data, where possible. The TA will leverage the local 
knowledge, existing structure, and network of MSME agencies and ensure that the COVID-19-
related support to MSMEs under the TA is complementary, gender-responsive, and sustainable. 
 
13.  Output  2:  Micro,  small,  and  medium-sized  enterprises  access  to  business 
development services and finance improved. The TA will help MSMEs, including women-
owned MSMEs, enhance their capabilities and recover from the effects of COVID-19 by accessing 
business  development  services  and  finance.  The  TA  will support MSME  agencies  provide 
effective business development services to MSMEs in their respective DMCs by strengthening 
their business support functions, which includes (i) reviewing training materials; (ii) building 
capacity of staff; and (iii) exploring appropriate online platforms for sustainable and cost-effective 
delivery of training to MSMEs. The TA will help MSME agencies develop and strengthen the toolkit 
for undertaking MSME viability and resilience checks and assess the impact of the pandemic on 
their revenue, profitability, and overall operations.21 The TA will organize a regional event for 
knowledge sharing on the recovery of MSMEs among all 14 Pacific DMCs.   
 
14.  The TA will support MSMEs to adjust to the environment created by the pandemic by 
providing  business  advisors.  The  business  advisors  will  help  MSMEs  (i)  analyze  market 
information, rethink opportunities, and diversify business lines; (ii) link to new markets; (iii) reorient 
the business operations of MSMEs using technology;22 and (iv) develop crisis management 
policies and business continuity plans to manage future disruptions.23 The TA will strengthen the 
financial capabilities of MSMEs by training MSME staff on better record keeping and financial and 
cash flow management practices; reviewing, updating, and stabilizing their financial position, 
including developing business plans and proposals for accessing finance; and linking businesses, 
when appropriate, with ongoing financial and technical support programs, including value chain 
finance.24 The  TA  will  strengthen  MSMEs  financial  reporting  by  aligning  it  to  the  relevant 
accounting and auditing standards, acceptable to financial institutions. 
 
15.  The TA will strengthen financial institutions' capabilities to underwrite and manage MSME 
loans in Pacific DMCs, including but not limited to Samoa, the Solomon Islands, and Tonga by 
(i) developing gender-responsive policies and products for MSMEs; (ii) assessing their adoption 
of financial technology solutions for contactless delivery of financial services to MSMEs, including

identifying relevant pilot projects; and (iii) building institutional capacity.25 The TA will also explore 
alternative sources of finance for MSMEs and coordinate efforts with the Pacific Private Sector 
Development Initiative, Phase IV on capital raising initiatives such as peer-to-peer lending and

16.  The TA will take a targeted, demand-driven, and differentiated approach, whereby support 
will be provided to sectors and MSMEs that are most affected by the pandemic and are critical to 
broader economic recovery. The national definition for MSMEs will guide the TA where possible. 
MSMEs, including women entrepreneurs selected for support under Output 2, will be identified 
through entry points or referrals from MSME agencies in Pacific DMCs, including, but not limited 
to the Cook Islands (Chamber of Commerce), Fiji (MSME Fiji), Samoa (Samoa Business Hub), 
Solomon Islands (Business and Cooperative Division), Tonga (Business Support Division), and 
Vanuatu (Chamber of Commerce). Selected MSMEs will be assigned business advisors with the 
necessary expertise. Business advisors will be engaged in close coordination with the existing 
Business Link Pacific program.26 The TA will prioritize the use of Business Link Pacific’s pool of 
local advisors to deliver Output 2. An impact evaluation will be undertaken as and when needed 
to assess the impact of targeted support provided to MSME agencies, MSMEs, and financial 
institutions. The project team will collaborate with regional and Pacific country offices, and ADB's 
ongoing COVID-19 pandemic-related operations that targets support to MSMEs to increase 
awareness of this TA. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $3,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB's 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF)—$808,000 from TASF 6 and $2,192,000 from TASF–
other sources. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  ADB will administer the TA through its Pacific Liaison and Coordination Office in Sydney. 
It will implement the TA over 48 months from 1 January 2021 to 31 December 2024. The 
responsible TA officer will oversee the day-to-day operations of the TA. Consultants that are 
recruited  will  comply  with  applicable  ADB  policies  and  guidelines.  The  TA  will  use  ADB's 
Knowledge Nexus to ensure broader coordination with other ADB departments and store all 
knowledge produced. The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

19.  Consulting services. The TA will require 130 person-months of national individual 
consultant services and 70 person-months international consultant services. ADB will engage the 
consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its 
associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions.27 A national individual 
consultant, selected using individual consultant selection method, will support the implementation 
of TA Outputs 1 and 2. For the remainder of consultants, a firm will be recruited using quality- and 
cost-based selection method. Given the ongoing travel restrictions, the use of national consultants 
will be prioritized by the firm with an estimated input of 100 person-months. International experts 
will remotely support national consultants. Virtual channels will be used for knowledge-sharing 
sessions and ongoing consultations with governments, MSME agencies, financial institutions, and 
relevant stakeholders. 
 
E.  Governance 
 
20.  The project team will hold quarterly meetings to discuss the implementation of activities 
under the TA. The meeting will be chaired by the regional director of the Pacific Liaison and 
Coordination Office. Representatives from the various divisions, resident mission and regional 
offices, the Pacific country offices, and relevant stakeholders as appropriate, will be invited to join 
these meetings.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $3,000,000 on a grant basis for 
Supporting Recovery by Micro, Small, and Medium-Sized Enterprises in the Pacific from the 
Effects of the COVID-19 Pandemic, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Enabling environment for recovery and development of micro, small, and medium-sized 
enterprises strengthened 
1.1 Undertake scenario analysis that supports recovery and development of MSMEs by June 2022 
1.2 Assess online channels to facilitate coordination among MSME support programs by December 2022 
1.3 Undertake a feasibility study for a national digital one-stop MSME information sharing platform and 
identify a pilot project by December 2023 
1.4 Undertake relevant diagnostic studies related to MSMEs (including gender analysis) at the national 
and/or regional level to inform future policy interventions by June 2024  
1.5 Review, assess, and develop policies and legislation that support MSME development by December 
2024 
 
2.  Micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises access to business development services and 
finance improved  
2.1 Develop and review training materials for MSME agencies, train their staff, and assess their options 
to deliver training using online channels by December 2022 
2.2 Develop and review toolkits for MSME agencies to undertake business health and resilience checks 
by December 2022 
2.3 Fund business advisors to provide direct business development and advisory support to MSMEs by 
December 2024
